content: How can I help you today?

I’m not sure how to start, but it feels like everything is off balance right now. My wife and I have been struggling to help our son with his behavior, and it’s causing constant tension at home. It’s all I can think about, and it’s affecting everything—work, time with my daughter, even just feeling normal.

That sounds like a really overwhelming experience. Balancing so much—your son’s needs, your relationship with your wife, work, and your daughter—might feel like you don’t have much space to catch your breath. Can you tell me more about what’s been going on and how it’s been affecting you?

It’s just that my son has been acting out a lot lately, and nothing we try seems to work. My wife and I don’t agree on how to handle it, which has caused a lot of arguments. I feel torn because I want to help him and be there for my daughter too, but I’m just...exhausted. I don’t know where to even begin fixing things.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy load right now: trying to support your son, maintain your relationship with your wife, and still be present for your daughter—all while feeling completely drained. It must be really tough to face so many challenges at once, especially when you feel unsure about the path forward. Where do you feel the strongest pull to focus right now?

It’s hard to say. I feel like my son needs the most help, but I don’t know how to help him. My wife is so frustrated, and I’m scared we’re just growing apart. And then there's my daughter—I feel like I’m failing to show up for her too. It’s like everything is crumbling, and I don’t know where to even start.

That sounds incredibly heavy, feeling like you're being pulled in so many directions and not knowing where to start. It shows how much you care about your family—you want to help your son, support your wife, and be there for your daughter, but it’s left you feeling overwhelmed and stuck. What’s been keeping you going during all of this?

Honestly, it’s been tough to find much that keeps me going. I guess the hope that maybe things can get better keeps me hanging on. I don’t want to lose my family—I just don’t know if I have the energy or know-how to fix this.

Holding onto hope, even when it feels like things are unraveling, says a lot about your commitment to your family. It sounds like this period has really drained you, but that hope—no matter how small it feels—is an important part of moving forward. What would feeling like things are getting just a little better look like for you right now?

I think it’d look like my wife and I being on the same page about how to handle our son—that would honestly take off so much of the stress. If we weren’t arguing so much, maybe there’d be space to focus on helping him and reconnecting with my daughter. It just feels so far away right now.

It sounds like finding a way to work together with your wife could really ease some of the tension and create space for you to focus on what matters most—helping your son and reconnecting as a family. Even though it feels far away, it’s powerful that you’ve identified what could make a real difference. What do you think might help you and your wife start working toward being more on the same page?

I'm honestly not sure. Every time we try to talk about it, it just turns into another argument—we’re both so frustrated and tired. Maybe it’s deeper than just parenting disagreements, but I wouldn't even know how to start fixing that.

It sounds like those conversations with your wife feel like they’re stuck in a cycle of frustration, which makes it even harder to solve things together. It’s really insightful of you to notice that it might even go deeper than just the immediate parenting concerns. Recognizing that is a big step. What do you think the two of you need right now to have the kind of conversations where you feel heard and connected?

Maybe we just need someone to step in and help us talk through everything without it getting so heated. I can tell we both want what’s best for our family, but it feels like we’re just stuck in the wrong ways of communicating. It’s hard to see a way forward on our own.

That’s a really thoughtful insight—you both care deeply and want what’s best for your family, but it’s sounding like the way forward might involve some extra support to break those patterns and create a space for understanding each other. Reaching out for that kind of help shows a lot of strength and dedication. What might it look like to take a small step toward finding that kind of support?

I don’t know—it feels strange to even think about bringing someone into something so personal. But maybe having a neutral person there could help us focus on solutions instead of just getting stuck in arguments. It’s just hard to admit we might need that kind of help.

It’s completely normal to feel hesitant about involving someone in something so personal. It’s also brave to acknowledge that it might help, especially when staying stuck feels so hard on all of you. Reaching out doesn’t mean you’ve failed—it’s actually a hopeful step toward the family and connection you care so much about. What would make taking that step feel just a little easier for you?

Maybe if I knew for sure it could actually help, I’d feel less unsure about it. I guess it would feel easier if my wife and I could agree on trying it together, instead of feeling like it’s just one more thing to argue about. I’m nervous about starting, but I also want things to get better.

That uncertainty is so understandable, especially when you’ve been through so much already. At the same time, it’s clear how much you want things to improve and how open you are to exploring a way forward if it could help your family. Agreeing on this step together with your wife could be a good way to feel like you’re working as a team again. Would it feel okay to approach her and share what you just shared with me—that you truly want things to get better and are open to trying this as a partnership?

I think that might help. It’s worth a shot to sit down with her and let her know I’m open to trying something like counseling together, but only if we’re both willing to commit to it as a team. I guess I can bring it up and see how she feels about it.

That sounds like a compassionate and thoughtful way to approach it—letting her know that you’re open, but also emphasizing the importance of tackling this together as a team. It’s clear how much you want to make things better for your family, and that’s such a meaningful step forward. Is there anything else on your mind that would feel helpful to talk through before you take that step?
